title: See how Trump's Big Beautiful Bill tax cuts will impact Texans
description: The average Texas resident will see a federal tax cut of about $3,942 in 2026 thanks to the "big, beautiful bill," according to an analysis from the Tax Foundation, a nonpartisan research group that mostly supports lower taxes.
content:
The average Texas resident will see a federal tax cut of about $3,942 in 2026 thanks to the "big, beautiful bill," according to an analysis from the Tax Foundation , a nonpartisan research group that mostly supports lower taxes.

Why it matters: That's money people can spend on rent, groceries or bills, which may be needed next year as inflation outpaces wages, and tariffs threaten to increase costs even further.

How it works: The spending bill not only made the 2017 tax cuts permanent, it added on new breaks: deductions for tips and overtime income, a cut for seniors and an expanded child-care tax cut.

Zoom in: In Harris County, the average tax break is expected to be $4,083 next year.

Zoom out: Travis County residents will see some of the largest average tax cuts in the state ($8,342), while taxpayers in the border counties of Zapata and Starr will see the smallest (just over $1,000).

Between the lines: There are broad geographic differences in tax benefits from the spending bill due to variations in state and local taxes, plus areas where more high-earners live, Axios' Emily Peck and Jason Lalljee report .

Reality check: The big bill also made some steep cuts to social spending on food benefits and Medicaid, but those mostly don't kick in until 2027 and 2028. For many lower-income Americans, those cuts will outweigh any benefits of these tax breaks.

keywords.name: Trumps Big Beautiful Bill tax cuts

summary: The average Texas resident will see a federal tax cut of about $3,942 in 2026, according to an analysis from the Tax Foundation. The bill also included new tax breaks including a cut for seniors and an expanded child-care tax cut. This money can be used for rent, groceries, or other expenses due to inflation and potential tariffs. The tax bill also made significant cuts to social spending on food benefits and Medicaid, but these cuts will outweigh the benefits.
shortSummary: The "big, beautiful" tax bill will provide average Texas taxpayers with a $3,942 tax cut in 2026, with regional variations noted.
argos_summary: In 2026, the average Texas resident is projected to receive a federal tax cut of approximately $3,942 due to a new spending bill that makes the 2017 tax cuts permanent and introduces additional deductions. The tax breaks vary significantly across counties, with Travis County residents expected to benefit the most at an average of $8,342, while those in border counties like Zapata and Starr will see much smaller cuts. However, the bill also implements significant cuts to social spending on food benefits and Medicaid starting in 2027 and 2028, which may negate the advantages of the tax reductions for lower-income Americans.
